member.name: T:XAct.Settings.IApplicationSettingsService
member.summary:
The contract for a Service that returns readonly Application Settings, common to all instances of the application, irrespective of the load balanced Host it is running on.
Very often, the service is implemented using XAct.Settings.ApplicationSettings.AppSettings
Important: although the notion of ApplicationSettings are umbiqutious, there are several disadvantages to using ApplicationSettings versus ProfileSettings (that *can* includ readonly settings, which is the same as ApplicationSettings). One of these is that Application Settings are not serializeable (a separeate mechanism has to be created to push them to a RIA client) and are more an old school web server, or WinForm concept.

member.name: P:XAct.Settings.ApplicationSettingAudit.CreatedOnUtc
member.summary:
Gets the date this entity was created, expressed in UTC.
Member defined in .
member.internal: There are many arguments for wanting variables of a certain type to be grouped together by Type (DateCreated, DateUpdated,DateDeleted) and it's very very tempting...but in the long run, I can't see it being right decision to go against the whole nomenclature of C# just to give better Intellisense in VS...
As to why its Nullable: sometimes the contract is applied to items that are not Entities themselves, but pointers to objects that are not known if they are

The value is Nullable due to SQL Server. There are times where one needs to create an Entity, before knowing the Create date. In such cases, it is *NOT* appropriate to set it to UtcNow, nor DateTime.Empty, as SQL Server cannot store dates prior to Gregorian calendar.

member.summary: A serializeable package of partitioned Settings, appropriate for an enterprise application that allows pluggable 3rd parties to employ settings as well.

member.summary:
The base , which is the true location of the to which nested s point back to.
Profile is a special case of

member.name: T:XAct.Settings.SettingGroup
member.summary: A Group of nested under a

internal.para: SettingsGroup is an interesting piece of architecture because SettingsGroup is actually a fake. It doesn't really have a child collection of Settings. It's just a mechanism to point back to the parent ModuleSettingsGroup (which is a SettingsGroup in its own right), which is where the true Collection of objects is located.

The reason for this architecture is that it is less iterative when loading/saving, so it can be used to pick up and save the variables with only one hit to the data persistence mechanism, rather than several, one for each variable group.

member.summary: Gets the ids of modules in app that user is allowed to use.
member.typeparam: The type of the id type.
member.internal:
In a multi-enterprise portal system, there could be hundreds of 3rdPartyModules - hopefully thousands.
In a single enterprise, there might even by many tens of modules that have been purchased for the app.
Hence, we dont' want to recurse through settings for each and every module - we just want the Modules loaded into this application instance, that the user has access rights to with the current Roles the user is a member of.

member.name: P:XAct.Threading.SpoolProcessor`1.MinimumNumberOfAvailableThreadsRequiredToRequestNewThreads
member.summary:
The mimimum number of threads required to be available prior to requesting new threads.
Explainatino:
Every Timer interval, the number of available threads is checked.
If the number of threads returned/available for re-issuance is less than this minimum threshold, nothing is done until the next timer interval.
The setting can allow some release of pressure from a server that is working extra hard.

member.name: P:XAct.Threading.SpoolProcessor`1.MaximumNumberOfNewThreadsToIssueAtAnyOneTime
member.summary:
Gets the maximum number of new threads to issue at any one time.
If the number of available threads is larger than , threads will be allocated. But to ensure that threads are not all in one go (spiking the cpu) no more than a certain number of threads are issued until the next Timer interval.
